commentBody:
Monday and Tuesday gave me hope.

Today did not dash it.

But also did not advance it.

I liked the theme and the puzzle.   Thanks to constructor.   
Though there were inconsistencies that gave some solvers problems, I appreciate the behind-the-scenes effort that the NYT team must do to quickly implement special cases like those icon squares, and try to get it to work for all the possible platforms and device versions the puzzle appears in -- no easy task.
rebus thingie won't let me correct an entry. keeps replacing my 1-letter correction with 2 letters.

I thought this was a pretty Lively theme for a Lively constructor. I‚Äôm sorry that technical problems soured this for some people, I did fine by assuming the picture stood for the letter and not filing anything in there; I would have thought they would have treated them like black squares and not allow you to fill anything there if that‚Äôs what they wanted. So if that messed people up that‚Äôs a shame.
Because I thought this was a pretty layered theme. At first I didn‚Äôt noticed the shaded areas and just thought we were replacing letterings with gymnastic moves. But in addition you had three very nice themers with hidden dances broken up by the letters which was nicely done, and a very clever revealer.
I‚Äôm also surprised everyone found this so easy. Not hard for me for a Wednesday by any means but at least average. Notice the double 10 stacks on either side in addition to the theme which is pretty unusual for a Wednesday and some clever clues‚Äîsound-track for ECHOLOCATE in particular, and CTSCAN for ‚Äúhealthy self image‚Äù. So, well done from my standpoint.
Super fun, I loved the theme and the appropriate dance figures. An enjoyable romp!

Why do I always enter him as LECToR? 
By now I really should know better!
Early week Puzzle of the Year contender!  Fun, light-hearted, as the column said.

This felt like a Monday to me. Clever yes, but also very dryly straightforward.  I think the idea started from a good place.  Might have been more fun had the characters been removed and thus turned into a theme less Friday with some tougher cluing.
I rarely noticed things like this, and it's probably already been mentioned, but I was amused that the same puzzle row contained NENE and NAYS.

I have a theory.

The black squares are unclickable.   You cannot get the puzzle to put focus on the black squares.

White squares are clickable, and when they have focus they are ready to accept input.

But these figure squares are a kind of hybrid--you can get the focus, that is you can click on them, but you *can't* do the input.

My experience was that I never saw the "Close" screen when I should have *assuming they puzzle knew that the figure squares did not require input*.

My guess is that the programming is such that the "Close" screen was confused by these "clickable" squares that  didn't accept input.

I think I should get the Nobel Peace Prize for this.  Does anyone have one they want to give me?
Cute. Much faster than average for me.

the gimmick of having to delete the dancer to complete was way beyond me. Spent longer trying to find the error than solving. 

Very much spoiled a perfectly decent puzzle. 

ü´§
Very cute and creative theme! üíÉü™©

"You said we would dance tonight! I came here under waltz pretenses!"

(Sometimes that's just the sway it goes.)

Is this a browser issue because of the exceptionally bad implementation of the Rebus system? I use Firefox. Should I load this on a Chromium browser? I avoid Chrome itself because it's determinedly anti-privacy in order to fit into Alphabet's business model.

This puzzle would have been SOOOOOO good without the even-worse-than-usual Rebus.

After completing the puzzle in what it was slightly better than my usual Wednesday time, I failed to get the happy music.  I had no idea that the clever little dance move spaces were rebuses; I kept trying to type over them.

In fear of losing my streak, I came here and found several helpful comments guiding me to use the rebus key on those squares. When I managed to highlight the graphic square and go to the rebus, I found an incorrect letter in each. Success - the streak remains intact

Feels like a frustrating technical glitch in an otherwise smooth and entertaining Wednesday puzzle.

I've tried this puzzle on Firefox. I've tried it on Brave. I've tried it on the iOS app (using IOS 26.3).

I've tried it with the letters under the dancers. I've tried it without the letters under the dancers. I've tried it with Rebus. I've tried it without Rebus.

I want my subscription fee back. This wasn't a puzzle. This was beta testing in production.
So easy i did it standing on my head with one arm behind my back

Surprisingly buggy implementation of an otherwise good idea for a puzzle. If there's a picture there, it shouldn't require invisible letter entry. 

Despite that, I got a new Wednesday personal best time, though it would have been at least half a minute lower if I didn't have to waste time figuring out why I wasn't getting the chime.
Clever! I enjoyed this one.
I always thought it was "Here, here".  As in "I'm here for that". TIL I've been saying "Hear, hear" all my life.
Enjoyed the puzzle, set a new Wednesday PR. But agree with others that the dancer icon was strange, should have showed up on finishing. Made the revealer redundant

I‚Äôm confused by commenters saying they had to enter letters into the dancer squares. I‚Äôm solving on an iPhone and just left those squares alone because they were already filled. That worked for me.

Based on comments here on days that involve unusual grids, there does seem to be inadequate UX testing across a variety of platforms. I have long since chalked that up to continuing contempt for online solvers.

Discounting user experience seems like a pretty bad idea, since I imagine most people are not printing and solving on paper, and it‚Äôs very easy to cancel subscriptions these days. Not that I will; I‚Äôm trapped under a 2176-day streak. But others will be stronger than I.

VISUAL AIDS indeed! An amusing irony considering the technical issue. 

I  very much enjoyed the clever theme and the artistic vibe of the puzzle. VINCENT VAN GOGH, the inner BALLET of HANNIBAL LECTER (picture that, if you will), and the ‚Äúsound-track‚Äù of MADONNA, HIHAT and CLEFS. 

On Sunday, in the midst of a blizzard, I saw The Sleeping Beauty ballet, which was a magical experience. Perhaps the lingering high from that experience made me enjoy the dancing silhouettes even more.

A lovely puzzle, thanks Brad!

Made my headspin, i did freeze when the app seemed to want me to fill behind the overlay, nothing that some fancy footwork couldn't get around. In the end an enjoyable puzzle with flare. Congrats to Brad for the power move.
Enjoyed Brad‚Äôs puzzle very much. I figured out the theme right sway (unusual for me!) and finished in record time. So sorry many had to face glitches; mine worked perfectly! üíÉüï∫

I‚Äôm totally perplexed. I‚Äôve completed the puzzle, and yet the Games page refuses to acknowledge this. I‚Äôve checked my answers against the answers page (which I‚Äôm entitled to do as a subscriber) and everything is correct. And yet my puzzle is deemed to be incomplete. Go figure! (And there goes my streak üòû)
Don't like this format.
This was my favorite Wednesdaybpuzzle in a long time! New ideas are always welcome!
Not my favorite. I had a typo behind one of the figures which took me quite a long time to chase down...

Set a new Wednesday PR with today's theme AND have gilded three in a row ü•π For a relative crossword newbie like myself, quite the accomplishment! Hoping tomorrow's potential rebus doesn't break me!
I really enjoyed the photo that accompanied the Wordplay column. Perfect for today's crossword, too.

Talk about a Lively puzzle!

What is it about graphics
that just amp up the 
fun-o-meter to

"Woo-hoo!'?

Everything everyone said, positive and negative!

I'm in purgatory. Time is passing but I can't move.

The puzzle is completed on my android phone. Back is disabled, as if my completed puzzle is correct. All the assist actions are grayed out. I've tried helpful suggestions in the discussion board. Icons are overwritten by letters. Rebus doesn't help. 

I have two choices: 1) Stare at my completed puzzle and watch the time tick up. 2) Go about my day, which includes shoveling the remainder of the 30" of snow on my walkways. 

I choose shoveling.

Forgive me, but I have a question about a different puzzle I hope someone can help me understand.

Tuesday's New Yorker puzzle by Paolo Pasco, 9A clue is "Mo" and answer is SEC

And I just cannot decipher it...

Too bad the technical difficulties are overshadowing what was otherwise a good puzzle.

Am I wrong in thinking the cursor jumped over those squares with the pictures, just like it does with any filled square? Or is my short term memory playing tricks on me? Because if I‚Äôm right, how would we know to go back and type over them?

The only way I could make the timer stop and register a completion was by clicking ‚Äúreveal puzzle‚Äù. It was hardly a satisfying end.

Has anyone run into this glitch?   Working back through the archives, I‚Äôm bumping into random puzzles I solved years ago, probably from when I tried free packs of, say, Tuesday or Wednesday puzzles.  

The odd thing is that the solve times for many of these old puzzles is ‚Äú0:00‚Äù!   Not a problem, of course. Just wondering if this has happened to other folks.
The puzzle is not finishing for me. I have everything filled in. I switched to list mode and I can see i must typed the wrong letter for one of the pics but I can't correct it. Im in limbo. Boooooo

I couldn‚Äôt stop the timer until I tried typing a T over the first dance square and held it down. The T didn‚Äôt enter, but suddenly puzzle finished and timer stopped.  Not sure if that‚Äôll help others?
Delightful trick in this puzzle. The fighter got me in the end but I really enjoyed the solve. The constructors are getting more creative by the day. More, more, more!

Got my best Wednesday time on this one. Clever theme. Had to check a few American sports things, but that's par for the course and no biggie. Agree the online grid could have been designed better to show the letters with the pictures and make it clearer for solvers - learn from that NYT digital developer team!
Thanks Brad!

I found this a very enjoyable puzzle to solve, although, curiously, some of my favorite parts were not theme-related:
HEAR(! Hear!) paralleling HUSH(-hush)
(Aural) ECHOLOCUTE paralleling VISUAL AIDS.

A little disappointed that there wasn't a post-solve animation of the little dancers, but I guess that would be too much to ask.
The Schr√∂dinger rebus makes another appearance.

When I finished the puzzle it just sat there but when I corrected my one wrong letter, I got the music. Weird. I could tell it wasn‚Äôt recognizing that the dancer squares were filled but it wouldn‚Äôt let me fill them. But in the end it worked when I had everything right.  I felt bad for those with a good streak going.
I can't get the puzzle to complete in the electronic version, and it won't let me change any of the letters. 300+ day streak on the line. Ugh.

This is Brad‚Äôs second NYT puzzle.  His first (3/27/25) was remarkably clever ‚Äì felt like it was made by a pro and showed great promise.  This follow-up shows that it wasn‚Äôt a one-off.  This is a crackling good Wednesday puzzle.

Break dance moves, pictured visually, actually breaking types of dances spelled out?  That is a brilliant constructor-mind stroke for a theme.  

Truly, it's a virtuoso leap from BREAK DANCES to break-dance-images-within-dance-names-within-larger-words.

No unclued or gibberish theme answers.  Everything works.  Just a masterful concept and design.  Bravo, sir!

Lovely wordplays in [Demo graphics, maybe] for VISUAL AIDS, [Signs of treble?] for CLEFS, and [Sound-track?] for ECHOLOCATE.  And a prime non-wordplay clue in [Taps casino table] for HIT ME.

I hope to see your name atop a new puzzle, hopefully soon, Brad, and when I do, my anticipation will soar.  Thank you for today‚Äôs splendid outing!

This puzzle was super frustrating, because I knew all of the answers, but could not get the app to show completion. The "V" would automatically change to the letter "A".I tried fixing this several times, but there seems to be a bug. My streak is ruined.

While I sympathize with puzzlers struggling with today‚Äôs technical problems, I think it‚Äôs worth remembering that any streak you have remains intact whether it is recorded by the NYT or not.  The streak count provided by the NYT is just a digital inducement to keep solvers coming back for more.
I was on a roll and then I got tripped up at the end by REZ and MILLI. But cool puzzle!

Sorry to those having app issues.

Theme didn‚Äôt feel contributing to the puzzle - just hidden stuff that only makes sense after the solve. 

My advice is to ignore the figures and the shades and it becomes a basic Monday puzzle.

I liked seeing MADONNA cross DI SCO, as I consider much of her earlier, dance music to be disco, but then, I'm pretty liberal with my definitions of musical genres. And older Detroiters will reminisce about espying Madonna on the dance floor at Menjo's, but sometimes I think they're just imagining. And, although I have not read the books, I can imagine Hannibal Lecter listening to Tchaikovsky or Delibes, although I would expect the coolness of Bach or Mozart to be more of his taste. But did Vincent Van Gogh ever tango? Well, typing "Van Gogh Tango" into YouTube's search box produced a surprising number of hits! Here's "Tango Van Gogh" by the Seattle-based cellist/composer Bradley Hawkins (although what it has to do with Van Gogh, I don't get, at least out of context): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UUhR98cyYM4&list=RDUUhR98cyYM4&start_radio=1 Here's a tango, "Opasan Ples," by the Serbian group Van Gogh: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-8EtvKd55TY&list=RD-8EtvKd55TY&start_radio=1 Finally, here's "Van Gogh Tango," from "Kiss & Tell Cabaret," by Jeremy Limb, Lloyd Evans and Melinda Hughes, and sung live by Ms. Hughes. I admit, I don't know enough about contemporary art to get all the references (but I know what I like), but I got enough. For a hoot, try listening to it with the CC on!: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=byBTou_EnSY&list=RDbyBTou_EnSY&start_radio=1

[Homer Simpson's words when channeling Hannibal Lecter and snacking on Mike Tyson]









MM ... A FIGHTER

I was able to get to completion in iOS by typing the appropriate letter on each dancer. The letter didn‚Äôt appear but I got the happy sound.

Fun puzzle!

This was such an interesting puzzle, but like many of you, I didn‚Äôt understand why I had to actually enter the letter the dancer represented. I had solved the puzzle and got no music. As I was checking the puzzle in list mode (is that what it‚Äôs called?) I noticed that VINCENT VANGOGH had the wrong letter where the dancer was. When I fixed the letter, I got the music. I feel bad for Brad Lively that his excellent puzzle was overshadowed by technical glitches. Don‚Äôt they test these things first?

So cute!  At first I thought it might be Ilan doing his signature back flip. LONG time since I‚Äôve thought about break dancing. 

Evidently many folks are having to type the letter, which would be a pity. Worked fine for me‚Äîmaybe they fixed it.

On the technical issue:
I had no problem with the fact that you needed to type over the dancing figures.  When I finished the puzzle, and the app didn't acknowledge that I was done.  I quickly figured out that was the problem, and went back and typed in the letters.

Having done that, the app acknowledge I had finished, but I got the dreaded "something's amiss" message.

And here's the problem I have with this:
Whether you type in the right letter or a wrong one, nothing changes with the dancing figure.  So you can't know if you've accidentally mistyped.
I re-typed all the "figure-letters" and something's still "amiss".

Well, I had a mistake else where (thinking that REZ was REs, and not checking the cross), and that's on me.
But I still think there needs to be a way to know whether you've got a typo on the figures.
Whoosh! That's the sound of the breaking of the dance words going right over my head. Excellent puzzle Brad!

Two obvious theme songs for today! Tiny dancer in my hand https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yYcyacLRPNs and miming letters, You can do whatever you feel https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CS9OO0S5w2k The lyrics aren't synched with the video, and they don't do the letters! Per Brittanica, the letter miming came from "a performance in 1979 on the television show American Bandstand. As the Village People clapped above their heads during the chorus, the audience mistook the group‚Äôs clapping motions for making the letter ‚ÄúY.‚Äù Immediately, the audience responded by spelling out the song‚Äôs name with their arms. The Village People not only joined in the moment but also added the choreography to their future performances." By the number of comments so far, I assume the graphics must not have done well in the online puzzle. No problem with pen-on-paper! A "lively" and enjoyable puzzle, Brad, thanks. now, to go look up "emo hair"
What, no animated breakdancers when finished?  C‚Äômon NYT techs!

Well... I was appropriately puzzled by this one for quite a while, but with a lot of working the down crosses finally tumbled to the trick (more or less). Wasn't sure what to do with the dancer squares but managed to work it out. A kind of cute puzzle find today. A Thursday from February 19, 1998 by A.J. Santora. Theme answers in that one: TEETERTOTTERED TAKESTWOTOTANGO TICTACTOE TOOTTOOTTOOTSIE TURNSTHETABLES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/19/1998&g=16&d=A ....
I finished the puzzle correctly, but it's not recognizing it. The only kps ticking and tells me I'm close, but no mistakes pointed out!

I had EAR hair for the edgy trend.  I don;t know what EMO hair is.  I didn't know what the Mil authority was.  And I had A?A FIGHTER and couldn't come up with an answer -- probably because there isn't one.  So a Wednesday 2-letter DNF.

Oh, yes, the theme.  They're putting teensy tiny little drawings in my grid again and I can't make them out.  Who keeps doing this?  Today, I wrote the letters I wanted there in dark, dark ink, obliterating the tiny little drawings.  Take that, tiny little drawings!

When I finally got to the theme, however, I thought it was quite cute and clever.  And those teensy tiny figures -- were they supposed to be dancing?  I left the "C" figure untouched since it looks like a C and therefore wasn't annoying me.  I can see it in its pristine, unobliterated form and I STILL can't tell if it's a dancing figure.

A nice puzzle if you overlook the indecipherable tiny little drawings that did little more than annoy and confuse me.  I know, I know -- I'm no fun at all.

For those with tech problems. The puzzle locked (on my android tablet) and would'nt allow me to enter or revise anything (acted like it was complete but the timer stayed running), so on a whim I tried the app from my android phone and entered the letters represented by the figures and voila, got the puzzle complete notification. Hope this helps some folks.

Finished with personal best on the iOS app without any of the glitches reported by others. I did put in the ‚Äúmissing‚Äù letters when the cursor moved to the dancers, more out of instinct than anything else. This week‚Äôs puzzles, as noted by others, has been somewhat topsy-turvy for me, finishing well above my average time on both Monday and Tuesday while doing my dance to the ‚ÄúSan Jose Strut‚Äù before the coffee finished brewing this morning.
Thank you for insisting I watch that performance. A whole vibe, indeed.

Did anyone else get tripped up by ____hair? There is actually a thing called "Emu hair" for obvious reasons, so I put that in and couldn't for the longest time figure out what kind of ratio started with a "U". Of course it finally dawned on me, and then I had to contend with putting the letters in the little figures. Not an enjoyable solve, but mostly my fault.

Wow, that's a lot of Comments for this early-ish hour.
Is it the little dead insects on the piece of paper?  (I used my swivel magnifying glass--brass, with engraved "Pearl B. Waddell, M.D."--my great-aunt--on the case.)  This revealed a hand-stand on Square 18...T-shaped; a fall victim in Square 30...Y-shaped, but intended as a V; and in the box adjacent to Square 49, a sky-diver frantically searching for the emergency chute release, possibly a portion of the letter K.

Thanks, Brad Lively.  Interesting.  (Don't quit your day job.....but seriously, please do construct more puzzles.  Loved the challenge!)

I remember when OLGA Korbut first competed in the Olympic Games way back when.  Like OLGA, Time flies!

Not to one-up Nora or Andzrej, but I crushed it with my absolute PB ever, while changing the the brake pads, turning the rotors and rotating the tires on my 4Runner.
Theory on today's glitch:
They did it on purpose to squash any criticism of the ease of which today's puzzle was solved. Just when we plebeians thought we finally stuck it to the man, he found a way. Where is Ron Swanson in all of this?
Hey NYT, why won't the timer shut off on my PC? Can't enter letters in break dancing boxes.

Ooookay‚Äîyou know that you can zoom in on the digital grid, right? Do that and the little dancers are suddenly great big dancers.

(I was surprised that I had to go back and fill in those three letters, but that‚Äôs on the digitizing crew, not the creator‚Äîand it wasn‚Äôt hard to figure out, imo.)
I typed in all the letters, can‚Äôt find any mistakes in list mode, and the clock keeps ticking. Really hate it when the gimmick goes wrong

Nice to have a little gimmick on a Wednesday! I totally torqued my back and hip shoveling on Monday, so my first thought looking at the little figures was OUCH! My second was "What are they doing? Well I guess the puzzle is for figuring it out."
And I did. 
Hi from snowy New London CT where we are getting 1" of snow, which would be picturesque if it wasn't adding to the 2 ft. already on the ground. 
Have a good day.
I really loved this puzzle!

Thought this might've been my best Wednesday at 6:57, but was actually 31 seconds shy. I did lose a few seconds having to enter the letters for the break dancer squares after completing everything else.

I think this one was programmed wrong. I finished (without putting anything in the dancing figures). I got the dreaded almost there popup. This generally means that you filled everything in, but you have a mistake somewhere. After searching hard for mistakes, I finally just put letters in to the dance figures squares. Success!! But it shouldn‚Äôt have given me the almost there popup if technically I had three blank squares. Or am I missing something???

The technical issues drove me crazy. At the first place where I encountered one of the small images, I tried entering the T in CREDIT SCORE but when no T showed up in my gird, I decided that the trick was to let the dancing images just stand in for the letters. When I finished the grid, not filling in any of the other squares with images in them, I got the close but no cigar message, then spent five minutes going over and over and over the grid. When I found no errors, I broke down and looked at the completed grid the Wordplay column links to just to finish the thing...and found no errors, and the squares with the dancing images are blank. Finally, I decided to try treating each of the three squares as a rebus, but with only one letter in it...and got the star.

What puzzles me is that if we were to do that, enter a letter in those squares, since I did not even try to enter a letter in the "dancing squares" at 29A and 46A, but there needed to be something there, why did the puzzle give me message that I had completed the grid but had errors message...and why did the model grid show blanks in those three squares?
 
Aside from that, the puzzle was fairly easy -- even with spending five minute searching for errors, I still finished roughly 30 percent under my Wednesday average.

I did want to say that I appreciated the juxtaposition of 31D and 32D (HEAR and HUSH)...and also the cluing for 11D ("Sound-track?") for ECHOLOCATE.

Typing a V over the V in Van Gogh got me to completed. The T and the C still did not let me overtype in the square. 

Tech problems take a lot of the fun out of puzzle solving
typing the v in the middle is what completes it!

To add to the discussion, I did the puzzle on my laptop. I recognized the graphics as standing in for letters and didn't type over them. I completed the puzzle (without lookups) and got the gold star!! I also finished the Tuesday puzzle without lookups. Yay! And I'm almost finished with the recommended also-dancing puzzle by Paolo Pasco--without any lookups so far. I saw Paolo Pasco on Jeopardy recently. I wonder--is he a dancer? Or what is his connection with dance? https://www.tvinsider.com/1215361/jeopardy-paolo-pasco-champion-facts-puzzle-writer/ So many great dancing movies. Always loved them. Starting with Carousel, I guess. Sign me--Newbie bragging!!

"So-called" melting pot.

Not so much anymore, tragically.  Catastrophically.

It‚Äôs about 6:30 am PST and I completed without entering anything in the break dancing boxes. 
Fun puzzle. As ever, amazed at the creativity in our puzzle makers. 
I remember Olga and her rivalry with Nadia in 1976.

This was fun! Yes, it seemed obvious to me that we needed to enter the missing letters in the pictorial squares, because the cursor landed there (making each a non-blank square). I did that on each pass, but I can imagine it was frustrating if you got to the end without having filled them in and thought you had an error somewhere. It seemed intuitive to me.

I think it was an excellent feat that Brad Lively found all these answers that fit the theme in three ways: With a dancing ‚Äúletter‚Äù in the middle, plus a dance name in the answer, plus a satisfying length. Bravo, Brad! I look forward to more of your puzzles.
Can someone explain how INRI = Concerning? I cannot find a reference to it outside of its biblical context.

I suppose more correctly called ‚Äòmoves‚Äô, but still, STEPIN seemed theme-ish.

I had no problems despite the reports of busted moves.
Fun puzzle.

Great puzzle spoiled by the inadequate visual extras. Spent forever trying to see the ‚Äòerror‚Äô only to find I needed to enter the letters in the image square, despite them not actually appearing at any point on my iPad. I hadn‚Äôt read comments as I was happy I‚Äôd completed correctly. Rats.

Frustrating enough to make me consider cancelling my subscription. I entered letters for the little figures, I deleted letters, I used rebus to enter letters, I checked the answers multiple times. 

The human figures in the shape of letters--in, out or in-between--are graphic glitches that make me feel a fool for even trying to finish this puzzle. Bleah!

Using the NYT Games app on my Android phone. Had grid correctly filled in, including the letters in the "dancer" boxes. Clock still going. Checked the contents of the "dancer" boxes using Rebus function. Discovered a glitch with the "T" in CREDIT SCORE. Whatever I enter into that box, it gets converted to an "R", so puzzle cannot be completed.

One more puzzle find. A Sunday from December 30(!) 2001 by Elizabeth C. Gorski with the title: "Dropping the ball." One answer: 16 down: "Midnight" And then 25 down "Cry heard shortly before 16 down." And those answers - mostly rebuses: TEN NINE EIGHT SEVEN SIX FIVE FOUR THREE TWO ONE I T S TWO O O TWO Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/30/2001&g=82&d=A .....
So what is a STANNED ?  St Ann Ed? Stan Ned? I finished but don‚Äôt know what this one is
It's a neat puzzle, and I enjoyed it for a Wednesday. However, the pictures did make it a bit difficult to work around

Nothing works. Not replacing dancer, leaving dancer, won't be
left blank. Bah.

It would have been a fun puzzle if I didn't need both the answer key and then these comments to figure out why it wouldn't finish. Since the picture didn't change when I put the letter T in 17A, I assumed they should remain as pictures. It wasn't until I checked myself twice, then twice again against the answer key, THEN read comments here that I went back and tried again. The pictures still did not change when I put the letters in, but once I at least tried the correct letter on all three squares it finally finished (although the pictures never changed). Very annoying and a waste of my time trying to find my "error".

I'd completed 17A and 27A before realizing that the gyrating figures in the boxes represented the letters themselves, so it seemed unnecessary, especially since whatever I actually entered didn't appear anyway. So I didn't bother with the "C" in 46A. I ended up retracing every clue, checking the spelling for "Actor Steven...", etc., and nothing seemed to work, so this is the first puzzle in 11,788 where I turned to the comments for help. NYT Puzzle Editor team, I'm afraid you've been hoist by your own petard on this one.
I have no idea why I could not ‚Äúfinish‚Äù. I still don‚Äôt. Lousy way to lose a streak! I have no errors but it shows incomplete. Boo!

Advantages of solving on paper:

1.  You don't worry about your time.
2.  You don't think about your streak.
3.  You're not concerned about "hearing the music" at the end of your solve.
4.  You don't have to think about whether you need to enter letters on top of the dancing figures.

I'm reading about so many problems with this one. I didn't try to replace the figures with letters, just worked around them and successfully completed the puzzle.
I do the puzzle on an android phone, usually on a wepage. Long ago I had an issue with the puzzles not saving my progress. I'd go back to the puzzle at a later time to find a blank grid, or quite a few of the answers missing. Tech help suggested using a webpage instead of the app so that's what I do most of time now. I still get that bug now and then, even with Spelling Bee. I'll get to whatever level and go back to work on it later, and it has reset, all gone! Anyway, sorry for everyone's troubles, I hope they take note and fix it for next time.

Not a fan of this one.  Wasted way too much time trying to figure out why my ‚ÄúfInished‚Äù puzzle was not accepted as ‚Äúfinished.‚Äù  Went over the completed grid twice, then went through the answer key, twice.  Constructor ‚Äústretched‚Äù a bit with this one.

Well.

I greatly dislike the recent litany of "too easy" comments; I find them tiresome when a puzzle can be appreciated for its craftsmanship but is instead panned for being "Monday-level" or worse.  It is disrespectful of the author.

However...

As I sailed through the across entries, I knew that the comments section would be flooded with haters.  I had many more squares filled than my usual first pass.  But apparently the difficulty issue was eclipsed by technical snafus that I, thankfully, did not experience.

This being said, wow, that was easy.  The only roadblock was STANNED which I let stand (heh!) because the crosses were so strong.  I didn't expect the music, but there it was.

Clever puzzle with a two-pronged gimmick.  Let's keep that thought foremost and blame the editors and IT people for any problems in placement or presentation.  Give the author a break (dance).
Got the whole thing right, but no congratulations and no streak.

Thank you, Brad, for the clever grid -- I thoroughly enjoyed it and had no issues typing letters into the body graphic squares (using a Mac laptop).

Thanks, Sam, for recommending we view Alysa Liu's gold medal Olympic performance -- just stunning! Like you, I've not had a lot of time to watch live Olympic events. Alysa's skating performance was just pure joy encased in gold!‚õ∏Ô∏èüèÖ

As a father, I mildly resent the term "dad joke," since we are no more or less prone to tedious attempts at humor. 
That said, the NYT crossword seems to have taken the idea of wordplay or puns in the grid from cleverness to dad joke all too often -- tedious, a long hike for a short reward, and certainly not funny. 
Raise your hand if you broke into a guffaw or some childish grin in awe of the break dancing gimmick. 
On a daily basis I complete the puzzle and say to myself, "It wasn't funny or interesting, but it was a gimmick." 
Here's a riddle: What's the point of a joke that isn't funny?

I came to the column thinking there would be a lot of fans of this crossword, not only using dancers to shape letters, but have those letters "break" a dance... so clever!

I was not expecting almost everyone to have solving problems. For the record, I solved on my android phone in the app, I entered the V in VANGOGH just because I didn't want to pause typing, but I skipped the dancer squares in the other two theme answers. I got the finished music and gold star, no problem. Maybe the glitch was fixed?

I finished but I have no idea how. I finished the puzzle, but it didn't stop the timer or play the "finished puzzle" music. I tried to replace a few of the gymnastics figures with the actual letters, but that didn't seem to help. Suddenly, the timer stopped and said I finished the puzzle. There was definitely a problem with the mechanics of this one. My actual finished time and my recorded finished time are about four minutes apart, not that I really care about my average time.
I agree. This puzzle is an ‚Äúabsolute vibe!‚Äù  My wife and I loved this for all its lively elements.  Including breaking up the dances. And it worked flawlessly on an iPad.

Like others, I had the problem that I finished (solving on a laptop) and did not get the gold star even after flyspecking for mistakes. So I switched to the phone app, used the list view of the answers, and found that some of the breakdancing squares had random incorrect letters filled in  (not sure if I had inserted those letters or a computer glitch did so). But when I fixed those letters in the app using list view, I got the gold star. No way I could have found this on the laptop since those squares just included the breakdancing pictures.
Weird that you had to put the letter into the square, as though it were a rebus, in order to have completed the puzzle, rather than just letting the drawing be good enough.

I have completed this puzzle correctly (I'm certain), but the counter keeps ticking. Exitig the puzzle and reopening gives a message that I still have clues to crack. It won't allow modifications to the letters. I have tried re-entering actual letters over the breakdancing symbols but that didn't help. Kinda frustrating!

I gather that there were technique-al issues for some.

Song of the day is "Wango Tango," by Ted Nugent, for obvious reasons. You got to pretend your face is a Maserati.

This got more and more fun as I gradually understood the intention. I thought the dancers were birds but I knew what letters they represented.   I solved from top to bottom so the revealer was a good surprise.  Perfect puzzle for a rainy Wednesday morning. 

Had to look up MMFIGHTERS.

Today‚Äôs poem made from today‚Äôs puzzle:

a/ time
melting
second by second
vanishing
like bubbles
d/ pop
pop
pop
and there you
a/ are

One more fun surprise today, solvers: There's now a Midi, as in medium-size, daily crossword, too! (Mini, Midi, Daily... didn't Caesar say that?) You can find it on the website or in the Games app. Just promise me you won't stop solving this one.
Super fun!

Too easy for a Wednesday, but fun - I liked Hannibal Lecter. I really, really didn‚Äôt like the fact that there were three (3!!) casino/gambling-themed words. So sick of the gradual and persistent creep of betting and gambling parlance into everyday life, and especially into the NYT crossword. Just why!

One more late puzzle find. A Sunday from November 25, 2007 by Trip Payne with the title: "Two out of three." Some theme answers: ROBROYROT MADMAXMANMAYMARMAT BIGBICBIZBIO FOEFORFOX HAGHASHAYHAT SADSAMSAWSALSAYSAX PUGPUPPUN And there were a couple more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/25/2007&g=115&d=A ....

Had difficulty getting the solve to go not because of the technical issues but rather because I had an I instead of an E in the NW corner. 
Took quite a while to realize INRI and KINO was in fact not what I was looking for!

Such a shame that so many encountered tech glitches! My solve was smooth, letting the dancers stand in for the letters, and I wish more people had experienced the same. I thought the puzzle was brilliant, what with the figures making BREAKs in the DANCES. It also hit close to home for me, having been BALLET-trained (and maybe one da I'll tackle TANGO), as well as having been there for DISCO in its heyday. But it's not a DISCO song I leave you with. Rather, I choose to honor MILLI Vanilli, that much maligned duo whose story is heartbreaking. https://youtu.be/RdSmokR0Enk?si=swgp0w_gRk6WZ1YX And here is a worthy interview with Fab Morvan that was recently published (RIP Rob Pilatus): https://www.theguardian.com/music/2026/feb/01/milli-vanilli-fab-morvan-interview-grammy-book-you-know-its-true) Thank you Brad for yet another creative Lively puzzle!
Am I the only one who didn‚Äôt see the little figures? I only knew after I checked out Rex Parker‚Äôs puzzling

Good thing I'm retired now and have more time to work on the 
nouveau Crossword (and the other NYT Games)!
Just tried out the new Midi Puzzle. (Scroll down for Sam Corbin's announcement).  Not bad (3:02) I guess but got confused - anyone who has been near a lightning strike would not use that word.

Absolutely horrible programming.   I typed the letters in the dancer boxes. No music. I tried using the rebus button. No music.  Switched to my phone and used the by line entry. Entered the letters and got music.  There is an easy solution to problems like this and filling in a rebus.  Don't use those squares when checking the puzzle.  Treat them like they are black squares. Problem solved and happy puzzlers.

Not sure if anyone addressed this (I don't really want to read through 300 comments), but it's Donna Summer's "rendition" of songwriter Jimmy Webb's amazing song MacArthur Park. There are lots of great renditions (as a trumpet player, my favorite is Maynard Ferguson's), but let's give credit to the songwriter, without whom all these versions wouldn't exist.

Second puzzle in the last few days where I finished it, but it did not signify it was complete and I could find no errors and there were no corrections after asking NYT to reveal the puzzle.  I'm fairly new here, is this a common or frequent issue?
Wow Alysa Liu surely is a great skater! üíØ I didn‚Äôt see all of them either. Thanks for showing us. It was an inspiration.

I‚Äôm confused by Wednesday‚Äôs puzzle. I completed the puzzle, but there was still at least one error according to the pop up window. I finally revealed the puzzle and there were no errors! What am I missing?
Luckily I didn't have any of the technical troubles others had with this puzzle. I thought the theme and the grid art was a lot of fun. The revealer did get a chuckle out of me; I'm easy to please.

Anyone else having trouble getting this puzzle to wrap up?  I‚Äôve checked and rechecked, even ran ‚Äòcheck puzzle‚Äô which resulted in no additional cross through marks to indicate an incorrect letter.  The time elapsed counter continues to roll and I never got the happy ‚Äúyou got it!‚Äù reinforcement song to indicate the puzzle is finished.
I've never seen a CWP where symbols are oriented so as to resemble the letters the take the place of.  Nice idea.  Otherwise a very straightforward puzzle today.
New PR Wednesday for me! Fun puzzle, thank you!

I feel cheated! I lost my streak! In didn‚Äôt realize I still had to enter the letters T, V, and C in the squares with the illustrations
  I went over & over the puzzle a million times, puzzled as to where I could have made a mistake! NOT FAIR! No indication what was needed, I AM POd!!!
Refuses to take the V in Vet and Vangogh. Keeps changing it to a E.
What is going on.  I cannot get a complete signal.

This is a very worthy Monday puzzle, and I finished below my Monday average time . But it isn't Monday. The theme was fun and immediately gettable, but adeptly executed.

Of note, it's important not to confuse a tic doc (neuro) with a tick doc (ID, or in this case VET)
Ices..... Hmmm

This was lots of fun; thanks Brad Lively!
I only read a few of the comments from today, but see some complaints and claims that a letter had to be entered in the squares with human break dancing shapes. Maybe it depends on what device one is using? On both my Mac laptop and my iPhone it worked without having to do that. Something strange seems to be going on.

I loved the puzzle and I also loved your comments, Sam (as I always do). Your first paragraph describes my experience exactly!
My husband watched quite a lot of the Olympic coverage but I popped my head out of a book, or a crossword, only once in awhile to watch an event. He recorded everything though, and insisted I watch Alysa Liu, and indeed, she was amazing and so joyful. I was really glad he made me sit down and watch it. :-)
So. Much. Fun!
Can't blank out squares containing figures. What gimmick am I missing after all these years?

okay, i just wanna say...  i thought the figures were the letters and didn't realize i had to add the letter on top of the figure as an overlay.  and so i'm trying to figure out what i got wrong forever..

answer, i got nothing wrong.  

having a graphic in a square that signifies a letter is hella confusing in terms of needing to put a letter on top of it.  grrr.  waste of time.
Does every puzzle need a gimmick?

This was fun, I‚Äôve been glowing off Alyssa Liu for days now. Haven‚Äôt had such a good time watching a performance since ‚Äú100% Pure Love‚Äù on RuPaul‚Äôs Drag Race. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_YZ22KEafkc
Loved it! So many fun clues.
What a yawner and a twee trick that nearly broke my streak because the silly graphic words wouldn't register as completed. One of the worst puzzle gimmicks ever.
Just popping in here to ECHO Sam in saying that "sound-track?" and ECHOLOCATE are the clue/answer pair of the year so far.
@Nyeth Certainly set my Wednesday best. But I did feel like I struggled through it as I solved.

@Nyeth

My time turned out considerably longer than it should have been because I didn't get the completion jingle when I finished.

I assumed a typo because I didn't come across anything doubtful in my mind, so I went through the clues, one by one, looking for a mistyped letter.

I couldn't find any.  I went through the whole thing again.

Then, I just decided to try typing in the three letters at the overlays, although I thought I had done that already. 

Apparently, the V was missing (although none of the three were visible).  The music plays, and that was that.

But I still thought the puzzle was fairly easy (but not too much so), yet clever, due to the multilayered theme.

Steve,
I assume you solved on your phone? On the PC, I didn't need to enter any letters in the three picture squares. (I checked the online version after solving the puzzle offline.)

@Steve L

I had a lot of technical trouble with this, too.  Trying to enter the letters with the figures, which didn't seem to work, nor did it seem to take the entry.

@B

I did it on the app and didn‚Äôt fill in any letters in those spaces

@SP

The minds at the Times have really innovated, introducing flyspecking to the comments section.  Had I not read carefully I would have missed the existence of your triply nested reply.  And now I assume this one is nested 4-deep.  Such winning.  Such vision.

@Steve L I had a nearly identical experience - except at first I did not type any letters in the overlay squares.  I only did that in all three squares when I fly-specked a couple of times and was sure everything else was correct.

@Nyeth
Yes! I finished in less than half my usual Wednesday time and 2 minutes quicker than yesterday's time. I figured out the entering of letters over the dancing figures because I got some sort of yellow highlight in the square and I was like, oh I guess it's expecting an entry there üòÖ

@Barry Ancona

No, I was on my desktop when I was solving. When I typed a V in the correct spot, the music played.

@Nyeth

It would have been about average time for me except that I lost a few minutes, figuring out the north east corner.
@Nyeth I beat my average by about half - 13 min and change. Very, very easy.
@Paul I feel like us Aussies are at a disadvantage today: those figures don't look anything like what we apparently recognise as the theme!
@Luke, that ‚ÄòC‚Äô is 100% Raygun.

@Paul

What is this apparently Aussie-specific Raygun, for the sake of the rest of the world?

@Steve L

Raygun was the Australian woman competing in the break dancing competition at the 2024 Olympics. Her moves were not modern, state-of-the-art break dance, and she was roundly razzed for it.
@John Kroll same.  I looked over the puzzle 3 times to find a mistake before doing that.
@John Krollyup. I broke a streak

@John Kroll
Yes and no. Though it took me some time, it was a pleasant ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment when I figured it out. But I do see your point.

@John Kroll

I solved in the app on Android and didn't have to add in the letters. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
@John Kroll - I did not have to type letters over the dancers.  I left those squares alone.
@dizzyspins Same here. After fly-specking twice, too. I mean, those squares already had letters in them!
@John Kroll When I clicked the arrow to go to the next word, it landed on the breakdancer square. At first it seemed a bit odd, but then I realised. Fun puzzle!

@John Kroll
The giveaway was when the last letter was entered but the focus didn't jump to the next answer.

@Barry Ancona

It was already linked in the Constructor's Notes.

Steve,
My link in the comments will be helpful for many people...
@Kate G use the rebus function- at least that worked for me

@Kate G
You don‚Äôt need to.  They are the images of the human body in stances that resemble the letters they represent.

@Miri 

Rebus function does not work
@Kate G I had no issues, maybe try retyping a letter next to the image?

@Kate G

I could, but didn't try it vertically, only horizontally.
@Phredo that‚Äôs a shame. It worked for me in the app on my iPad. Technical issues are very frustrating, indeed.

@Barry Ancona

I get the music repeatedly by just revisiting the solved puzzle.  And that's without erasing anything.  This is via the web version.  They've royally messed things up.  See also my previous observation that the timer just keeps running if you leave a puzzle open after solving completely.  And that the "Admire" button now does nothing.

@Barry Ancona

As far as I can remember, the jingle always played whenever you reopened a completed puzzle. At least in my setups (PC and iPhone).

@Steve L
I remember the jingle always playing whenever I reopened the puzzle too ‚Ä¶ but I wish it wouldn‚Äôt. I like the music when I first solve it, but it‚Äôs annoying when I‚Äôm trying to write comments. If I don‚Äôt go back to the puzzle in a set amount of time (2 minutes?), it reopens the puzzle and plays the music again. It‚Äôs so unnecessary. I solve on an iPhone.

@Steve L

This never used to happen in mobile browser.  Jingle on first solution only.

@john ezra

lol I tried emu hair first too
I don't know about emu hair but one should be warned to be very careful when getting down from an emu.
@john ezra what are the udds of that?

@Keith
Is that like "you can't put too much water in a nuclear reactor?"

Jim,
See my post a few minutes ago supporting your observation.

@Jim

And my reply.
@B Do those stats even mean anything in the early hours of the crossword‚Äôs lifespan? I imagine it‚Äôs all the hardcore crossworders (is that a word?) flocking in to fill the puzzle before bed.

@Stepan

No idea really.  The ratings don't seem to change more than a grade throughout a puzzle's day span.  I'm not a registered user.  I only peek on over there because others have cited them as a reliable indicator.  I would guess (?) they hold back a few minutes to gather at least a few hundred votes before posting.  For me, the consensus there seems to agree with my experience no more than about 70% of the time.  This marks I think the 3rd time this week that my rating would have been wildly different from their stats.
@Stepan that‚Äôs probably most people that do it lol

@B

I think the rating, (Easy, Hard, etc), is stable but the median solve time does grow.  One example given here last week went from roughly 14 minutes to 17 minutes by 7:45AM (+20%).  I assume it would keep growing up to 10PM as the late returns come in.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Nope, I saw the last one I monitored flip back and forth between Easy and Average over the course of hours. It was this past weekend.

@SBK
Oddly, I only had to over type one of the dancers when it suddenly told me the puzzle was complete.

@A progressive
I agree....I've been doing the puzzles online since they became available online and readily completed the answer key but was repeatedly informed that the it wasn't successfully completed.

I then typed in delete for those three squares and I got the jingle for a successful completion.

It shouldn't have to be that way as there was no "instruction" concerning this odd step.
@A progressive same, I always knew my streak would end on one of the gimmicky puzzles.
@A progressive. That‚Äôs a real bummer, no cap.
@Joe P same here., in fact the puzzle locked and wouldn't let me make any changes even though it said it was incomplete

@Selective Walrus

Try screwing around and putting letters into the squares with the graphics.  I suspect that at least one of them is expecting an input even though it should not.

@Selective Walrus

Ok I closed the app, reopened it, then re-entered the letters behind the breakdancing. That seemed to trigger it, though it wasn‚Äôt triggering the first time I was doing that before rebooting.

@Selective Walrus

Yeah, I'm generally pretty careful, but I found I had to re-enter the T in tide. I though I had entered all the graphic letters.  Based on others' comments I'm thinking it sometimes chooses to ignore us.  This was not a great experience.  It's been a bad month 'round here.  Maybe they replaced a lot staff / outsourced?

@Selective Walrus I've also correctly completed the puzzle without getting the gold star. I've tried to enter the appropriate letters where the graphics appear, but the app on my phone is not allowing me to change any letters in the puzzle. I've restarted my phone. Still no success. Then, I logged out of my account and logged back in. Still no success. I guess I'll try my laptop. This is why I hate these gimmicks. Such a waste of time.

@Selective Walrus 

I went onto my laptop where I was able to enter the appropriate letter behind each graphic. Now it shows up with the gold star on my phone.

@Keep It Simple Please

You may have an error.  The Success screen seems to be working (kind of), but the "Close" screen isn't showing up at all, at least not for me.
@DawnW - I didn't have to type in any letters over the dancers.  I left those squares alone.

@DawnW

I just typed the letter in as usual and it advanced to the next square as it normally does. The images are presumably meant to resemble letters but not to replace them. Looking at the comments, I must be the only one who didn't have a problem with this.

@Teresa
Same.
@Teresa, me three!
@jennie Me too. So now there are at least 4 of us.

@Teresa
yes, me too. I typed in the letters just to advance to the next square without using the computer mouse. On the first one, I expected the letter to replace the dancer, but no problem when it didn't. It must've been very frustrating for those who didn't type the letter when they didn't get the music.

@DawnW 

I tried both ways. No music. Checked the grid twice (across and down) first against the clues and then against the answer key. Tried deleting the squares with pictures since I couldn't be sure whether any response from me was entered. Still no music. Tried entering the letters for those squares. Nope. I can be a little slow but I realized that I could find out whether there was a problem by checking the comments. I did think to order them according to the number of responses. But I had already done what people were saying worked for them. Since I was working on my (Android) tablet using the games app, I decided to try something else. Pulled out the iPhone with its app, but no luck again, though the time it gave was lower. Went to check whether I did/did not have anything typed in those squares. Deleted what may have been in the first, deleted what may have been in the second -- Bingo! Music!
Have added a total of about 15 minutes to my time, but my streak is intact. At least I think it is. Last time I lost the streak, I got a gold star that was  taken back a day or two later. We'll give it a few days!

Hope this helps someone who may still be having problems.

@Stephen

That poor old dead horse has been thoroughly beaten in recent weeks.

But you are correct.  It would be sweet if the editor gods would deign to comment.

I wouldn't hold my breath.

@Stephen

As Francis said, the horse is dead as a doornail. But I will add one thing‚Ä¶

Used to be, although the editors always (or at least almost always) arguably made it *possible* to solve a given puzzle without prior knowledge of arcane trivia or especially esoteric/contrived vocabulary, the puzzles also reflected a clear willingness to stump/frustrate/defeat the average solver.

That was just part of the deal ‚Äî sometimes even early in the week! And while that could indeed be frustrating at times (at least for me), what you got in return as part of that bargain was a steady supply of genuinely challenging puzzles (along with plenty of easy ones, to be clear).

For the moment, I‚Äôm afraid the editors seem to have lost that willingness. Here‚Äôs to hoping they regain their nerve soon, and the current participation-trophy era ends up being a merely short-lived phase‚Ä¶
@dutchiris For me, it wasn't.  In fact, I only got credit for completion when i *emptied out* the letters that I already HAD entered.

@dutchiris
 
I didn‚Äôt get the gold star until I selected one of the break dancers and hit the Delete key. Nothing changed, but I had ‚Äúsolved‚Äù the puzzle.

@Venk Natarajan

@dutchiris - I did not need to enter the letter.  Done on a Samsung Android phone in the app.
@Eric Hougland my experience as well.

@Eric Hougland
It sounds like the app puzzle was buggy. I hope that's the most annoying thing that happens this week.
@Stepan  Hence the question mark.

@Stepan

"Healthy" as in health-related.   They are health-related images of one's self.  It's reasonable wordplay.

@Mike 

Same thing happened to me.

userLocation: Skipped the SOTU, and glad I did!
commentBody:
@Steven M.
Nittle-de-dee!

@Steven M.
It's possible the intended answer is the generic "event," not "Event" - which I think makes the clue valid, since the mentioned things are as much Olympic "events" as is the guy in seat 22B of the curling venue getting up to buy a drink at the concession stand.

@SBK
Shout out to your new handle.
@Inchoate But Earnest thanks for pointing out that these are rebuses--I was stuck for so long wondering why it wouldn't accept my answer. This was pretty clunky implementation

@Inchoate But Earnest - same! My puzzle is complete but incomplete (?) and there's a E where there should be a C. Simple correction, right? It would be if the app would let me change it. So frustrating!

@Inchoate But Earnest interesting. I didn't use my rebus key at all and had no issues. Just entered the letter like any white square. I couldn't see my entry under the dancer, but it was accepted without issue in solving.
@Inchoate But Earnest the rest of the story: switching from phone to notebook & Chrome enabled me to correct the balky Lecter entry. Technology, schmectology.

@Patrick J. Thanks for pointing this out. I too always spelled it with an o rather than an E. Since I solve with a pencil on paper, I had no warning that this was incorrect except for the rather strange ECHOLOCATo.

@Shaun When I MILLI, I was sure there was going to be a Vanilli somewhere in the puzzle, but then what could that clue to? 45 down - with 26 across, the lip sync scandal duet of the 1990's Grammys? It's not like this is the Connections where made up words are tolerated. ;-) For all the folks who got stuck with the glitch - I ask for grace for the Gameplay team. The crossword started in 1942 as a diversion for the American people after Pearl Harbor. 54 years later, the first NYT crossword for the web was introduced in 1996 - it was a sign that the Times was embracing and not trying to bury their head in the sand, about what the world wide web was going to mean to their industry. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/02/14/crosswords/new-york-times-crossword-timeline.html The web itself has upped the ante for all content creators to embrace gimmicks and stunts, and the Times is trying to keep up while still maintaining its intellectual standards. I am going to guess that most of us are tail end boomers and early gen xers - The Times needs to fill the pipeline of later generation users and that means embracing the trends. They had 54 years to perfect the paper crossword puzzle, and we need to allow them room for error as they embrace technology.

That's what worked for me, too, but I don't think everyone had the same experience.

The dancers are an overlay.  The overlays can be removed in Settings, and if you do, you're left with a regular square where those three dancers were.  They should each take a letter.

There's no reason to consider using the rebus key, as some solvers tried.  There's no rebus here.

However, it seems odd that so many people are reporting so many differing experiences.  And as for me, I was pretty sure I entered all three letters in the initial solve, so I don't know why going back to the V did it (I tried re-entering the T first, but that didn't do anything, and of course, I didn't get the chance to try re-entering the C).

If anyone's streak was broken, just write to the email address above, in the heading.  They should be able to fix it.

Any puzzle can be made easier or harder by adjusting the clues.  That's what the editors do.

It's OK to get a Monday puzzle on a Monday.  This Monday's puzzle was easy and also very good.  But we don't want Monday puzzles every day of the week.
